name: Kwan-Yee K. Wong
content: ï»¿ Kenneth - Home Home Research Publications Professional Undergrad People Personal Links Prof. Kenneth K.Y. Wong BEng CUHK; MPhil, PhD Cambridge Associate Professor School of Computing and Data Science The University of Hong Kong Tel: (+852) 3917 8443Office: 323 Chow Yei Ching Bldg, Pokfulam Rd, Hong Kong Email: kykwongcs.hku.hk URL : http://www.cs.hku.hk/~kykwong [Research] [Publications] [Professional Activities] [Undergrad] [People] [Personal] [Links] Prof. Wong received the BEng degree in Computer Engineering, with first class honors, from the Chinese University of Hong Kong in 1998. From 1998 to 2001, he studied in United Kingdom at the University of Cambridge, where he was a member of the Speech, Vision and Robotics Group in the Department of Engineering. He received the MPhil and PhD degrees, both in Computer Vision (Information Engineering), from the University of Cambridge in 2000 and 2001, respectively. Since 2001, he has been with the Department of Computer Science at The University of Hong Kong, where he is now an Associate Professor. He served as the Associate Head of the Department from 2008 to 2012, and as the Programme Director of the BEng(CompSc) programme from 2008 to 2015. He has been appointed as the Deputy Director of AI Literacy Management Unit (AiLU) since April 2025, and as the Associate Head (Teaching & Learning) of the Division of AI & Data Science of the School of Computing & Data Science since June 2025. Prof. Wong's research interests are in Computer Vision and	Machine Intelligence. He is the Director of the Computer Vision Laboratory. His research works include camera calibration, shape and motion recovery, face sketch synthesis and recognition, scene text recognition, object retrieval, medical image understanding, and generative AI. He has published over 180 peer-reviewed journal and conference papers. Many of his works appear in top venues, including CVPR, ECCV, and ICCV (top conferences in computer vision), and TPAMI, IJCV, and TIP (top journals in computer vision). He is currently an	Associate Editor of IJCV. He regularly serves in the program committee of all major conferences in computer vision and AI, including CVPR, ECCV, ICCV, NeurIPS, ICML, ICLR, and AAAI. He is also a regular reviewer of TPAMI, IJCV, and TIP.
